text:
Depends on what flexibility and autonomy mean to you. For instance, do you mean set your schedule and take off when you want, like not work 40 hours or such? I ask, because depending on the role and/or level, some companies offer that. It also can depend on how good you get, how differentiated. That's because you can better work on your terms the more rare you are.

For instance, I combined my journalism background with strong business thinking (which I took pains to learn) and I work on my terms even as a full-timer at companies. I have the network and credibility to work solo, but I would have to give up the ability to influence, to help solve strategic business problems. No outsider can get into a business and have impact the same way an insider can, all else equal.

Just remember that all businesses strive for the best business outcomes. So that means whatever practices they have are negotiable if they think it worth their while. Like at my last job, my CEO boss let me spend company time advising other companies, because he wanted to retain me. I was there 7.5 years and always set my own schedule, had incredible autonomy, etc.

I'm now at another job with nearly complete control over my schedule, time off, etc. That's because we operate on high trust and focus on results.

text: Who has turned a 30-60 minute podcast and turned it into a summary/blog? I have a client who wants me to do this (using the actual podcest, or an <http://Otter.io|Otter.io> transcription) and create something that is about 250 words. I feel like I've done this before and it took a long while, so I'm not sure how to price this out. Any advice would be appreciated!

elements.text: Who has turned a 30-60 minute podcast and turned it into a summary/blog? I have a client who wants me to do this (using the actual podcest, or an
transcription) and create something that is about 250 words. I feel like I've done this before and it took a long while, so I'm not sure how to price this out. Any advice would be appreciated!

text: I’ve done plenty of these for webinars, but they are usually ~1000-1200-word posts that summarize key takeaways. So I price them as I would any blog post of that length. 250 words is so short! I wonder what value they’re actually looking to deliver with written content of that length. (A few examples: <https://www.sheerid.com/blog/how-asics-drives-double-digit-growth-with-zero-party-data/> and <https://www.montecarlodata.com/the-future-of-the-modern-data-stack/>)

attachments.fallback: SheerID: How ASICS Drives Double-Digit Growth with Zero-Party Data
attachments.text: Learn how ASICS’ is using innovative strategies like identity marketing to build meaningful and lucrative customer relationships in a cookieless world.
attachments.title: How ASICS Drives Double-Digit Growth with Zero-Party Data

attachments.fallback: Monte Carlo Data: What's In Store For The Future Of The Modern Data Stack?
attachments.text: Bob Muglia, the former CEO of Snowflake, discusses what’s next for the tooling and technologies powering data analytics and engineering.
attachments.title: What's In Store For The Future Of The Modern Data Stack?

text:
Thanks for the mention, <@U034H601T7X> :slightly_smiling_face:

There is some great advice already in this thread especially getting clear on what your goals are.

I personally do both content production and strategy as a solo, and love the mix that it offers.  (I've even dabbled in helping in-house content teams w/ hiring for content roles -both freelance and  FT.)

An alternative approach that might be a fit - and surprised no one mentioned it already - would be to either work in-house for an agency (results focused and async comms centered) or freelance for one.  That's a particularly good way to learn more on the strategy side as a freelancer.  (That's actually one of the things I did the first year I went off on my own.)

Happy to chat more if you have any ?s, feel free to DM me.
